moves.1. e4: Still the most popular opening move.
moves.1... e5: Probably the best reply even now.
moves.3. Nf3: The best play, forever neutralizing the threat of ...Q-R5 ch.
moves.3... Ne7: An unusual, and somewhat conservative, variant.
moves.4. d4: Seizing command of the center, as is always White's objective in this opening.
moves.4... g5: Adding support to the advanced KBP, but because of Black's 3rd move, the supporting Pawn itself is now vulnerable.
moves.5. Nxg5: White equalizes the material and aims his Knight at the weakened Black K-side.
moves.5... Ng6: Repositioning, with a discovered attack as well.
moves.6. h4: Rather than retreat, White adds support to the Knight.
moves.6... Bg7: Completing the fianchetto, attacking White's central Pawns, and preparing to castle.
moves.7. Bc4: Aiming at the usual target: the weak point at Black's KB2.
moves.7... O-O: Tucking the King in what Black thinks is the safest available spot, while adding a guard to the KBP.
moves.8... h6: The alternative is 8... R-K1, which allows 9 BxP ch winning the Exchange. However, this move allows a quick checkmate!
moves.9. Qxg6: Threatens 10 Q-R7 mate. If Black creates a flight square with 9... R-K1, 10 BxP ch gives Black the choice of 10... K-R1 11 Q-R7 mate or 10 K-B1 11 N-R7 ch with mate or overwhelming material gain for White to follow shortly.
moves.10. hxg5: Renewing the mate threat on KR7. Black resigns [10... R-K1 11 QxP mate.]
